We must continue to improve, strengthen and protect both Medicare and Medicaid. As we celebrate this anniversary, I commit to continuing the fight to keep these programs strong and ensure that Americans and their families have access to the services they need.

Unfortunately, today, these programs are under constant threat — the Texas vs. United States lawsuit supported by President Trump and Congressional Republicans could wipe away that progress in an instant without any plan to take its place.
In 2010, we built on that foundation with the Affordable Care Act and expanded the Medicaid program to cover millions more.
Fifty-four years ago today, the Medicare and Medicaid programs were signed into law, helping millions of Americans with receiving the care they need. pic.twitter.com/UTZ6g1bjB7

To make the #ADA goal of economic self-sufficiency a reality for people with disabilities, I introduced the Disability Employment Incentive Act (S. 255) to encourage businesses to hire more p/w disabilities. #ada29 #pwd https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/255?s=2&r=54 …

The #ADA offers a path towards a truly accessible nation and elevates the voices of millions of individuals. On this 29th anniversary of the signing of the ADA, we celebrate and will vigilantly protect those hard-earned rights. #ada29

On this 29th anniversary of the signing of the Americans with Disabilities Act, let’s celebrate some of the rights it affirms: the right to vote, to live where you want to live and to make your own decisions. #pwd #ada29
One of those Americans is Jean Searle, a Pennsylvanian who lives in Harrisburg. https://medium.com/@SenBobCasey/jean-searle-an-ada-life-97df7aa35058 …

As with the other great laws, the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965, the ADA was written to rectify discrimination and prejudice against a specific group, in the case of the ADA, those 61 million Americans with disabilities.
Last year, the Centers for Disease Control estimated there are over 61 million people with disabilities in the United States.

Today is the 29th anniversary of the signing of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), a statute that is sometimes called the last great civil rights act of the 20th century. https://medium.com/@SenBobCasey/jean-searle-an-ada-life-97df7aa35058 …

Clark McClelland of Pittsburgh was not only an Astronaut and designer of launch towers, but he also has the distinction of designing the now iconic Apollo 11 mission patch. https://www.wpxi.com/news/top-stories/apollo-11-patch-pittsburgh-man-designed-patch-for-apollo-11-moon-landing-spacesuits/968584745 …

Pennsylvania’s Alcoa built the lander’s shock absorbing legs. Even the pole Neil Armstrong used to plant the flag was designed by a Pittsburgher. https://www.pittsburghmagazine.com/Pittsburgh-Magazine/July-2019/From-Pittsburgh-to-the-Moon-Our-Role-in-the-Space-Race/index.php …
The Command Module Columbia, home for the three astronauts on their way to and from the moon, was designed and built by Pittsburgh’s North American Rockwell.

Glynn Lunney, a native of Old Forge, served as one of the three Flight Directors for Apollo 11. https://www.thetimes-tribune.com/lifestyles/old-forge-native-former-nasa-flight-director-looks-back-on-moon-landing-1.2507581 …

Today, in yet another malicious retreat from that vow, the Trump Administration announced drastic changes to that system. These changes weaken our moral standing around the world, give fuel to our enemies and make us less safe. https://apnews.com/6bef9ed6c48b4c2ea203cbbea3ccacad …

We established a legal asylum system in the wake of the horrors of World War II because we, as a nation, vowed to do better, to BE better, to serve as a refuge for those fleeing violence and persecution in their home countries.

“Go back to your own country” is an ugly and deeply xenophobic sentiment rooted in the darkest periods of our history. The fact that it’s coming from our President is beyond the pale. Once again, his words make us less safe.

En lugar de priorizar y deportar a aquellos que representan una amenaza para la seguridad pública, esta Administración ha elegido separar a las familias. Esta inclinación por la crueldad nos hace menos seguros y va en contra de los valores de nuestra nación.

En lugar de arrancar a los niños de sus padres y separar a las familias, el presidente Trump debe trabajar con el Congreso en un plan de inmigración bipartidista que asegure la frontera y ofrezca un camino hacia la ciudadanía para los inmigrantes que respetan la ley.

El operativo de ICE recogerá a niños y familias inocentes y marcara uno de los puntos mas bajos de esta administración, la cual a demostrado que es completamente inmoral y que esta vacía de decencia. https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2019/07/14/anxious-immigrants-across-country-fear-ice-deportation-raids/1717524001/ …

Instead of solely targeting those who pose a threat to public safety for removal, this Administration has chosen to rip families apart. This abject cruelty makes us less safe and goes against the values of our nation.

Instead of ripping children away from their parents and separating families, President Trump should work with Congress on a bipartisan immigration plan that secures the border and provides a pathway to citizenship for law-abiding immigrants.

Today’s raids, which will sweep up innocent children and families, will go down as one of the lowest points of a thoroughly immoral Administration that has shown itself to be devoid of decency.  https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2019/07/14/anxious-immigrants-across-country-fear-ice-deportation-raids/1717524001/ …

The Sirkorsky Coatesville employees deserve answers on the long-term viability of the plant and I look forward to hearing more from Lockheed Martin about a comprehensive plan to ensure livelihoods in Chester County.

However, while this announcement is an encouraging first step, I am concerned that the announcement lacks a specific plan to bring new work to the Coatesville facility that would keep the plant open beyond the next several months.

I am pleased that following the June 10, 2019 letter I sent, along with the efforts of @RepHoulahan and other local elected officials, Lockheed Martin heeded our call to keep the plant’s 465 workers on the job.
Today, I received word from Lockheed Martin that they are reversing their decision to close the Sikorsky helicopter plant in Coatesville.
